reviewText: Dodge
recommended: dodge. Shield. Forcefield. Damn that f..king forcefield isn't recharged"\nIt's a violentless roguelike quick-reactions 2D sidescroller quasar collector asteroids avoid game. That means you fly in space but don't have any shooting abilities. Your only 3 (defense) weapons are a ship protecting shield
hoursPlayed: a pushback forcefield (damn it needs about 3 secs to loadup) and a magnetic-like quasar autocollector. The aim is to collect about 110 quasars (diamond finish) in each of the 15 levels and beat the 3 challenging bosses in a chooseable difficulty. It's highly recommended to use a controller for that. The challenge rises during the level process. So it turnsout the game forces you to strategical thinking like "When do I activate the shield?" If every power ability coolsdown after very long 25 secs you cannot reuse it in the meanwhile. But you can improve your values in the upgrade screen after each round. Payed with in-game gained levelpoints (max 6). The background graphics look very fine. But the gameplay can be quite repetive if you must try over and over again the challenging levels and collect all of the needed quasars. Escpecially challenging are bossfights which are like a bullethell or dodging around sucking-in blackholes."

reviewText:
At first glance, this game was not something I liked or cared for in any general sense. Being an on the rails shooter bullet hell type game without weapons, you can imagine it became incredibly frustrating, very quickly. That frustration amounted to full blown hatred of the game, the 120 second timer, the lack of weapons and only 3 special abilities... but... after about 3 hours of game time, I realized that although I wanted to smash my head against the wall, I was actually enjoying trying to get 100 Quasars on each level (the white orbs you collect to win the level.... you need 100 on each level to fight the bosses). Sometimes the game seems impossibly unfair and about as challenging as walking to the moon on glass shards but when you finally succeed, you feel like you truly accomplished something that not every gamer would be able to do.  At this point, I've beaten the first nine levels and I'm on the second boss and I think I've met my match but considering I at first despised this game and now I've come to respect it, I'd say it's worth the money.
Pros:
-Hard, omg it's so hard
-Pretty nice graphics
-Winning feels like ejaculation. It's just wonderful.
-Easy to learn, with abilities that can save your ♥♥♥... a lot.
-Lots of unlockables
-Later levels become insanely fast

Cons:
-Oh my flying spaghetti monster, this game is so ♥♥♥♥ing hard!
-No weapons (you're meant to survive without getting hit, even in boss fights)
-120 second timer. That doesn't sound very long but when you've got about 5000 rocks about to smash into you, it is.
-It'd be nice if there was an easy
date:
normal or hard option" because this game defaults to ♥♥♥♥ING INSANE
-I know the story isn't a huge focus and from a fiction stand point is fine but scientifically it's like what? No more suns in the whole galaxy? Coooooome ooooon.

Final Verdict: If you like to rip the veins out of your arms one by one using a Toothpick then this game is for you. Bullet Hell types will find a lot of enjoyment here
recommended: especially out of the boss fights which really add in variety to the base gameplay. And if you're going to buy this game
hoursPlayed: don't judge it based on the first couple of playthroughs
voteText:
get all the abilities and play to the first boss and then judge it. Recommended for the masochists out there.

reviewText:
I'm writing this as I'm 2 hours into the game, I'll change my review if developers make some larger changes.

Story: 7/10
You are a tiny crew on a spaceship and you have to collect quasar, the only known energy source in the universe, but there is a strong militaristic alien species, Kryp, that wants to collect all the quasar, so you have fight against them. Story is simple, but interesting.


Graphics: 7/10
This is a 2D game, so there isn't much to talk about, effects are nicely done and backgrounds are pretty. I didn't notice any weird designs or graphic glitches. I have an AMD Phenom II X4 3.4 GHz and Nvidia GeForce GTX 650 Ti, and game is working on 60fps without frame drops.

Gameplay: 6/10
Gameplay is fast-paced and kinda hard, you have to collect quasar while avoiding meteors and enemies. Controls are simple, you move with arrow keys and you use shield with Q, slow time with W and use gravity with E. You can upgrade those powers in the upgrades menu, upgrades are nicely balanced so you are not OP. There are 3 bonus levels that you unlock as you progress in the game. The thing that bothered me is that ship feels dull and unresponsive so it's hard to steer it and avoid meteors and stuff, it would be easier if this game had a Xbox 360 controller support. And when you start the level, there is an intro and game suddenly starts after the intro, I think that it would be better to have something like a 3 second countdown before the game starts because it's a really fast-paced and all sort of things start happening suddenly.

Sound: 7/10
Sound effects are nicely done, voice acting is really good for an indie game and soundtrack is ok, nothing special, but it fits the game nicely.

Enjoyment: 7/10
I personally enjoed this game, it's hard, it's fast-paced so something is always happening, but it gets repetative after some time, but I got back to it after a break.



Final score: 6.8/10
I don't like games like this, but I like this one, it has some things that can be improved, so I hope that developers will get to it and make this game even better. I recommend this game if you like stuff like Space Invaders, Ballpoint Universe and Really Big Sky.

reviewText:
═══════════════════════════════════
OVERVIEW
ShipLord

ShipLord is a different take on the bullet hell genre. Instead of focusing on combat, the main goal is to collect an energy source for Earth called quasars. Gameplay is mostly dodging asteroids and activating skills to make that task easier. There is a shield that lets you smash through the asteroids, a time freeze, and an auto-loot skill that collects all quasars on screen. Collecting certain amounts of quasars awards points to spend to increase the duration or reduce the cooldown of the skills. Ranking in the platinum and diamond tier on each level will unlock new ships which each grant additional cooldown of the skills. After 4 levels collecting quasars there is a boss round where you dodge the attacks until an asteroid hits them.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/422250/

═══════════════════════════════════
PROS & CONS
Pros
Atmospheric music is very relaxing
The graphics are rather good
The hitbox is very precise enhancing the skill based aspect of the game
Controller compatible and responsive (recommend using a controller)
Controls can be reconfigured
Cons
Deadzone on the joystick could be better to prevent ghosting
The difficulty increase from level 4 to the bossfight on level 5 was unexpected
Only 15 levels
═══════════════════════════════════
SUMMARY & FINAL RATING
This game is rather fun, and the choice to leave out combat makes for fewer things to distract the player. Rather relaxing play. Avoid if easily frustrated. While it has only 15 levels there are bonus levels that are endurance focused with steam leaderboard rankings. This game is listed at about $8 USD and personally I would value this game at $5-6 USD. If you absolutely love bullet hell then this may be a great deal for you, otherwise add it to your wishlist so you can be notified when it goes on sale.

8/10
═══════════════════════════════════
For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow  Lot's O Giveaway's  group curations  here !

reviewText:
I've given this game a lot of thought and playthough and decided that I cannot recommend this even though the gameplay is quite original and I like supporting indie devs.

Long story short:
+unique take on an asteroid shooter -  avoding asteroids without really shooting much, main mission is to collect orbs
+decent enough for a few hours of playthrough a day
+the RPG elements and the upgrade system are good, but may have been added only to increase playtime

-clunky controls and only partial support
-repetitive music, mediocre sound and somewhat poor voice acting
-trailer makes a lot of bold claims like phenomenal graphics" which are simply not true
-the gameplay is very rudimentary and gets boring fast
-not that many missions available

All in all
date: this would be worth getting for the trading cards and to maybe try something new
recommended: but don't expect to play this long term"

It's not that bad, you simply collect quasars that randomly spawn on screen, and avoid asteroids that come from one side of the screen to another and it has modern graphics.

Its easy to just finish the game but it can be challenging if you want to go for full achievements, you can upgrade your ship to make things easier.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/7rpDtvDBWic
Game: ShipLord
Genre: Space Avoid-er
Developer: Just1337 Studio
Publisher: KupiKey
Copy supplied by developer

ShipLord is an indie space avoid-er developed by Just1337 Studio and published by KupiKey.

STORYYou play as the crew of a spaceship, whose goal is to collect Quasar, the only energy source in the universe, while also avoiding the alien specie of Kryp, who is after all the Quasar.
The story is pretty simple and straight-forward, and it lacks any depth, but it doesn't have to have one. Since it isn't the main goal of the game, I'm gonna forgive it for its simplicity.

GRAPHICSThe game looks surprisingly really good: the design of the ships is neither too detailed nor too simplistic, and the asteroids are mostly varied from one another. The background is gorgeous, with planets rotating and stars shining. However, more than once I confused an asteroid for a background planet, and vice-versa, resulting in my instant death, forcing me to turn off the planets from the Options menu to avoid further dying.

GAMEPLAYYour goal is to collect as many Quasar as possible while avoiding asteroids. You also have three abilities to use: a energy shield, a force field that stops the massive rocks in their tracks, and energy collection that instantly attracts every Quasar that has spawned. You will also battle bosses, which consists in avoiding their attacks for a certain amount of time.
As you can see the gameplay is very simple and easy to master. It is very reminiscent of some good old space games that managed to be both fun without requiring complicated mechanics and big variety.

CHALLENGEThe game gets harder and harder the more you play: the speed and amount of asteroids increases, and each boss has a precise pattern that you must follow to avoid being insta-killed.

SOUNDThe electronic soundtrack is pretty decent, and both sound effects and voice acting do their job. For being a first-time developer, it's pretty good.

REPLAYABILITYThere are 15 levels, as well as bonus ones, different skins for your ship, upgrades that feel a bit useless, and 9 Steam achievements for completionists. However, I believe that once you've beaten the game, you won't feel the need to go back to it again.

Overall, the game is a good space avoid-er that fans of the genre must play. If you aren't familiar with them, I recommend waiting for it to go on sale, since it is pretty good in it of itself, with some good-looking graphics and easy gameplay.

Story: 6.5
Graphics: 7.5
Gameplay: 7
Challenge: 8
Sound: 7
Replayability: 7

ENJOYMENT: 7
FRUSTRATION: 7

reviewText:
I like playing challenging platform games. I also like challenging space shooters. I like the concept of this game as well. What I don't like is that it only supports keyboard functionality. Yes I know that it's meant to be that way to give us that retro feel but personally I think it makes the game way too challenging for my taste. Making a game challenging for diehard fans is ok in my book but making a game impossible for the vast majority is not something I agree with.

I used the Xpadder 5.7 app to even get the scores that I did. This game definitely needs game controller support.

UPDATE: There is controller support now but it still won't work in Boss fights. Hopefully the upcoming updates will fix this. I like the tweaks that have been made to make this game very enjoyable so far & I like the fact that we are being heard. The continued improvements the dev team is making on this game have made me change my vote to positive.

reviewText:
Review + Giveaway x4
NOTE: extra keys provided by developer. I try to only review games I think I'll enjoy.

ShipLord is a side-scroller with a novel approach to level progression. Put simply: no weapons! Instead, you must quickly and carefully manoeuvre your spaceship to dodge incoming asteroids and enemy projectiles. You will be rewarded if you collect enough energy orbs along the way too.

Helping you to survive the onslaught of asteroids are 3 abilities: a shield which provides temporary invulnerability, a force field to slow down time and repel asteroids and a tracor beam

that pulls energy to your position. They're all upgradeable too, which is a nice reward between levels. Unlockable ships and bonus levels provide some extra incentive to score highly.

It's simple, addictive and exhilerating gameplay which quickly becomes challenging, not only because of the tricky asteroid projectories (and sneaky ultra-fast moon rocks!) but also due to

the lack of mid-level checkpoints. They wouldn't make much sense here however, because levels consist of surviving for only" 1 minute or so. Expect to repeat some levels a few times until you learn when and where the troublesome asteroids pop up.

Like the regular levels
date: ShipLord features inventive boss encounters too. For example
recommended: you must defeat the first one without using any abilities. Better hope your dodging skills are well-honed!\n\nMusic and sound effects did not have much of an impact on me
hoursPlayed:
but some of the voice acting is done well.

Gameplay is very smooth and it feels nice piloting the sapceship in and around the obstacles while collecting enough energy your nerves can risk going for. The 3D planets orbiting in the background are a pleasant distraction.

To summarize: the presentation is very nice and good attention to detail is evident throughout. Just1337 Studio have conceived an original game and executed it very well. This is only their
first release
voteText:
so I would keep a close eye on Just1337 Studio if I were you!


Giveaway here (ends December 31st 2015): https://www.bobmanbob.com"

Hey and this is my review about Shiplord!

About the game
The game is a fast paced Mini-bullet hell" sort of game.


You need to collect an ammount in order to get a medal and a level completion.

There are Bronze/Silver/Gold/Platinum and DIAMOND Medals.

Personally i find the controls a bit clunky/choppy. It would be better if you are able to play this game with a Mouse or a controller.

The arrow Keys on the keyboard is not working super great. Esepcially if you have to avoid things in a fast paced game

You are able to upgrade your ship by reducing or increasing some time.

Music is calm all the time
date: but it doesn't feel there is alot of variety into it.\n\nThe graphics are okay
recommended:
background is interesting.

There are "power abilities" Like shields
voteText: or energy collecting.\n\nThere are some lack of additional information

like What each uprades really do or meant. Or how many you need to earn a medal.

Some of the Texts has a very small font.

There is a notification speech when a ability is ready for use.


Objective about the game

You are a Ship and you have to collect white energy cells around space and avoiding incoming projectiles and asteroids.

The game does feel repetive after awhile

because the only thing what you are doing is collecting energy cells and avoid projectiles.

You need to get Gold medals in order to proceed further into the game. Gold medals are required in order to start the Boss.

You need to get all gold medals or higher in the previous levels in order to unlock the boss.

During a Boss Level you will encounter the "Mini bullet hell". The boss will spam projectiles and you have to avoid this.

But above all
votesTotal:
You have to survive until the timer is up. That counts for every level!.


Abilities/upgrades
There are Several Abilities and upgrades in the game.

Decrease energy Spawn time - This will increase the white energy cells spawning. (although 3 is max on the screen each time

Decrease Shield cooldown - I think this is one of the most powerful ability. This should be one the first upgrades to be maxed out.

Increases shield time - This will increase your shield time duration.

Increase Slow time - I find this ability of slow really useless and i rarely use it myself

i find this ability useless. But You can use this more often once upgraded.

Decrease energy collector cooldown - Once used all current energy on the screen will be teleported to you. Upgrading this is useful.

reviewText:
I don't remember the last time when I spent this much time playing a game for the first time. I started playing this just to kill some time, but then it became something much more.
The game develops nicely and with the time you put in, it becomes more and more rewarding. Story is catching, mechanism is nostalgic and old-school (in a good way ;)) and all this combined with today's graphics and design makes it into one of the best available games in this category.
If you like easy, time killing, monotone games - this is not for you. It takes skill and finesse to get to the higher levels and when you do get there, it gives you a special kind of satisfaction that only a few games can provide.

To sum it up; It's originality and clever development make this a fine addition to Steam. Calling this game just an arcade" is not descriptive enough to explain even in the slightest what this game provides.

Best advice I can give to anyone who's even a little interested in this is to give it a shot - you will not be disappointed."

reviewText:
This is a short game that you can easily beat in a few hours. If you're going for Diamond on every level you'll be in for some ride, though... A ride that's not really worth it. The boss fights (on Diamond) are frustratingly hard, and not for the right reasons. In order to win, you need to combine skilled gameplay (good) with memorization (not that great) and some luck (bad). This would not have been so bad if the controls were better, but they are not suited for precise maneuvering. Many good bullet hell games will let you slow down your movement by holding a button, but ShipLord doesn't let you to that, which means that you'll crash into projectiles that should've been easy to dodge.

A lot of the time I felt like I died not because of error I made but because of flaws in the game. Sometimes astroid formations are nearly impossible to dodge, and sometimes astroids spawn just as you pick up a point at the edge of the screen. Oh, and points sometimes spawn inside of astroids, making them hard to spot until it's too late. If you're unlucky they will spawn at the opposite side of the screen, thus not giving you enough time to pick them up unless you use Energy Collector".

The graphics
recommended: and voice acting are all below average
hoursPlayed: and there are a few grammar and spelling mistakes in the game. The game would've been better if it were in 2D and it would've been better without any story or voice acting
voteText: though that's a minor complaint.\n\nI give this game a 6 or a 7 out of 10. It is not entirely without merit

votesTotal: despite how frustrating it could be at times. It might be worth picking up on a game

reviewText:
Please note: I received a free key for the explicit purpose of reviewing this game. No one associated with this game has compelled me to leave positive feedback. Observations and comments, whether positive or negative, are entirely my own. If you would like me to review a game, check out: fiverr dot com slash ThatAwesomeTerr.

ShipLord is one of the better titles I have seen with an $11 pricetag. The game's store page content showcases pretty well what it is. Normally, arcade-style games like this aren't my cup of tea, but I am glad I gave it a shot.

The mix of mildly cartoonish 2D graphics with a pseudo-3D rendered enviroment is a little weird, but did not impact playability or enjoyment at all. The background environments can be really impressive, and did on one occasion distract me to the point that it caused my death.

Patience, timing. These are key elements to success when playing this game. There isn't any offensive game-play at all, so you can expect to spend most of your time dodging asteroids and enemy fire and activating any of your three defensive abilities.

There is also an upgrade and unlock system. With upgrades, you can incrementally improve your ship's various abilities to complete levels, such as increasing your shield duration or decreasing the time it takes for each ability to recharge. At the start, you only begin with your ship and no abilities at all. This made the first couple of levels a little boring to play, but things quickly ramped up in levels after that.

It seems like a bit of a big download at 8GB, at least to me. But, there are literally a TON of levels to unlock and progress through. Over all, I think this was a really fun game to play, and well worth the cash.
